question.text: What did God command Adam and Eve not to eat in the Garden of Eden?
options: The fruit of the tree of life
The fruit of the knowledge of good and evil
The fruit of the tree of wisdom
The fruit of the tree of immortality

question.text: Who tempted Eve to eat the forbidden fruit?
options: Satan
A serpent
An angel
Cain

question.text: What was the consequence of Adam and Eve eating the forbidden fruit?
options: They became like God, knowing good and evil
They were immediately struck dead
They were banished from the Garden of Eden
They lost the ability to communicate with God

question.text: What did Adam and Eve do after they realized they were naked?
options: They hid from God
They made clothes out of fig leaves
They asked God for forgiveness
They blamed each other

question.text: What was God's punishment for the serpent?
options: It would crawl on its belly and eat dust
It would be killed by humans
It would be banished to the underworld
It would lose its ability to speak

question.text: What was God's punishment for Eve?
options: She would have pain in childbirth
She would be ruled by her husband
She would be banished from the Garden of Eden
Both A and B

question.text: What was God's punishment for Adam?
options: He would have to work hard to grow food
He would be banished from the Garden of Eden
He would die
Both A and B

question.text: What did God make for Adam and Eve to wear after they sinned?
options: Clothes made of animal skins
Clothes made of fig leaves
Clothes made of cotton
Clothes made of wool

question.text: Why did God banish Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden?
options: To prevent them from eating from the tree of life
To punish them for their disobedience
To teach them a lesson
To protect them from further temptation

question.text: What was placed at the entrance of the Garden of Eden to prevent Adam and Eve from returning?
options: A flaming sword
A wall of fire
An angel with a sword
A giant boulder

question.text: What is the main theme of Genesis 3?
options: The consequences of disobedience
The power of temptation
The importance of trust in God
The origin of sin

question.text: How does the serpent's temptation of Eve relate to the concept of deception?
options: The serpent lied to Eve about the consequences of eating the fruit
The serpent tricked Eve into thinking the fruit was good for her
The serpent deceived Eve about God's true intentions
All of the above

question.text: How does the story of Adam and Eve's sin and punishment relate to the concept of free will?
options: It shows that humans have the freedom to choose between good and evil
It demonstrates that God allows humans to make their own decisions
It illustrates the consequences of making the wrong choice
All of the above

question.text: What is the significance of God making clothes for Adam and Eve after they sinned?
options: It shows God's continued care for them despite their disobedience
It symbolizes the covering of their shame and guilt
It represents the first animal sacrifice
All of the above

question.text: How does the story of Adam and Eve's banishment from the Garden of Eden relate to the concept of redemption?
options: It shows that there are consequences for sin
It demonstrates the need for a savior to restore humanity's relationship with God
It symbolizes the loss of innocence and perfection
Both A and C

question.text: What is the significance of the tree of life in the story?
options: It represents eternal life
It symbolizes the knowledge of good and evil
It represents God's presence
It symbolizes the source of all life

question.text: How can the story of Adam and Eve's temptation and sin be applied to our daily lives?
options: It teaches us to be aware of the consequences of our choices
It warns us to be cautious of deception and temptation
It encourages us to obey God's commands
All of the above

question.text: What can we learn from God's continued care for Adam and Eve after they sinned?
options: God's love and mercy are unconditional
God is always willing to forgive us when we repent
God's plan for our lives is not derailed by our mistakes
All of the above

question.text: What is the main takeaway from Genesis 3?
options: The importance of obedience to God
The consequences of sin
The need for a savior
All of the above

question.text: How does Genesis 3 connect to the larger biblical narrative?
options: It sets the stage for the rest of the Bible by introducing the concept of sin
It foreshadows the coming of a savior who would defeat sin and death
It explains the origin of human suffering and the need for redemption
All of the above

characters.name: Adam
characters.role: First man created by God, husband of Eve

characters.name: Eve
characters.role: First woman created by God, wife of Adam

characters.name: Serpent
characters.role: Creature used by Satan to tempt Eve to disobey God

characters.name: God
characters.role: Creator of the universe, judge of Adam and Eve's disobedience
